key_facts: The Scottish government reversed its ban on wood-burning stoves in new homes.
The reversal followed backlash from rural and island communities.
Original regulations aimed to eliminate polluting heating systems.
Bioenergy and peat-based systems are now allowed in new homes.
The change addresses energy resilience concerns in remote areas.
Supporters argued low-carbon alternatives are limited in rural regions.
Critics warned wood-burning stoves contribute to air pollution.
Health campaigners cited health risks from wood-burning stoves.
The revised policy still bans gas and oil boilers.
Flexibility is allowed for secondary heating sources.
Ministers say the update balances environmental goals and rural needs.
